abstract.p: The precise estimation of the Remaining Useful Life (RUL) of lithium–ion batteries is essential for averting unforeseen failures and enhancing operational efficiency and maintenance planning. This paper presents an advanced deep learning framework that couples a spatial-attention mechanism with a Transductive Long Short-Term Memory (TLSTM) model, augmented by one-dimensional dilated convolutional layers to capture long-range temporal dependencies. In contrast to traditional LSTM or GRU models, our methodology utilizes one-dimensional dilated convolutional layers to effectively capture long-range temporal relationships and implements a clustering-based Differential Evolution (DE) strategy for resilient weight initialization and optimization. This hybrid architecture boosts prediction robustness and solves the persistent issue of capacity regeneration effects, frequently neglected by previous models. Additionally, we offer a many-to-one multi-channel learning framework that incorporates several operational signals (voltage, current, temperature) instead of depending exclusively on single-channel capacity data. This invention minimizes parameter complexity while markedly enhancing generalization to unfamiliar settings. Extensive experiments performed on the publicly accessible NASA lithium–ion battery dataset reveal that the proposed model significantly outperforms existing state-of-the-art methods, achieving error reductions of over 10–14% and an exceptionally low Mean Absolute Percentage Error ranging from 0.0053 to 0.0095. These findings distinctly underscore the originality of our research: It represents the inaugural framework that amalgamates spatial attention-driven TLSTM with dilated convolution and clustering-based DE optimization in a multi-channel context, setting a new standard for precise and dependable RUL prediction in battery health monitoring and predictive maintenance applications.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: Lithium–ion batteries (LIBs) have become fundamental to contemporary energy storage systems, facilitating applications from consumer electronics to electric vehicles and extensive renewable energy integration1,2. Their extensive utilization arises from benefits including high energy density, lightweight construction, and comparatively prolonged cycle life3. Nonetheless, the efficacy of these batteries necessarily diminishes with time due to recurrent charge–discharge cycles, side reactions, and environmental stressors4. When capacity drops below a crucial threshold, replacement is essential to ensure safety and operating efficiency5. Forecasting the RUL of lithium–ion batteries has thus emerged as a critical research focus6, facilitating proactive maintenance, enhancing system reliability, and decreasing operational expenses7.

Precise RUL prediction is a fundamental element of contemporary battery management systems (BMS). Determining the end-of-life of a battery not only averts unforeseen failures but also aids in optimizing maintenance schedules, minimizing downtime, and prolonging the overall efficacy of battery-operated devices. Unsupervised prognostics identify aberrant, non-stationary decline in the absence of labels8. Liquid-cooled thermal management substantiates the preeminence of temperature in aging9. The integration of hybrid SOC estimation by metaheuristic optimization and machine learning enhances resilience and generalization across varying degradation levels, consistent with DE-based multi-signal fusion10. In extensive applications like electric car fleets or renewable energy storage, the capacity to predict degradation has considerable economic and environmental consequences, facilitating effective planning for replacements, recycling, and secondary utilization11,12.

Notwithstanding decades of advancement, forecasting RUL continues to be exceedingly difficult. Battery degradation is influenced by intricate electrochemical processes and nonlinear interactions among operating circumstances13, charging profiles, and environmental factors14. Furthermore, degradation does not consistently exhibit a linear decline; factors such as capacity regeneration induce irregular variations that traditional models are unable to account for15,16. These complexity require sophisticated methodologies that beyond basic statistical extrapolation or solely physics-based models.

Conventional empirical and physics-based models for forecasting the remaining useful life of lithium–ion batteries are limited by their dependence on assumptions and simplistic dynamics, hindering their capacity to accurately represent the intricate nature of battery degradation17. Consequently, data-driven methodologies especially those utilizing machine learning and deep learning have garnered significant interest due to their ability to immediately extract patterns from operational data. Nevertheless, despite their potential, these methodologies encounter numerous enduring obstacles18. A significant weakness is their dependence on single-channel inputs, mostly capacity data, which omits other valuable information like current, voltage, and temperature, thus diminishing the capacity to generalize across varied operating circumstances19. Furthermore, numerous models encounter difficulties in managing irregular patterns, such as capacity regeneration and nonlinear degradation, often leading to erroneous forecasts. Although advanced neural networks attain significant predicted accuracy, this frequently necessitates vast parameter sets and substantial training data, hence presenting issues with scalability and robustness. Ultimately, optimization challenges exacerbate model creation, as the initialization and training of deep neural networks are susceptible to local minima and sluggish convergence, while traditional gradient-based techniques may fail to produce optimal solutions for these intricate structures. Collectively, these constraints highlight the imperative to create creative frameworks that integrate effective feature extraction, adaptive learning, and resilient optimization methodologies to attain dependable and generalizable RUL predictions.

Each strategy encompasses distinct processes including crushing, melting, leaching, purification, and lithium recycling, culminating in the fabrication of new batteries.Fig. 1

This research is motivated by the urgent requirement for a dependable and effective model that can precisely forecast the RUL of lithium–ion batteries. Current methodologies frequently inadequately address the nonlinear and irregular deterioration patterns of batteries, such as capacity regeneration, or rely excessively on singular data channels, such as capacity alone. Furthermore, numerous deep learning techniques, despite their efficacy, are computationally demanding and susceptible to optimization challenges, hence constraining their implementation in practical battery management systems (BMS). A framework is necessary to address these limitations by effectively integrating diverse operational data, capturing both short- and long-term dependencies, adapting predictions to novel conditions, and ensuring robustness against noisy or incomplete signals, all while maintaining efficiency for practical deployment.

This paper presents an advanced deep learning framework that integrates multiple complimentary strategies into a cohesive architecture to fulfill these goals. The model fundamentally integrates spatial attention mechanisms with a TLSTM network. Spatial attention permits the model to prioritize the most salient features in multi-dimensional data, while the transductive nature of TLSTM facilitates local adaptation of predictions to novel samples, achieving a compromise between global generalization and local sensitivity. To augment temporal feature extraction, one-dimensional dilated convolutional layers are integrated into the architecture, broadening the receptive field without incurring extra computational costs and allowing the model to capture long-term dependencies and degradation dynamics across various timescales. The optimization of this complex model is enhanced by a clustering-based DE strategy, which facilitates more effective weight initialization by concentrating the search on promising solution areas, thus expediting convergence and minimizing the likelihood of local minima. The framework employs a many-to-one multi-channel design that concurrently integrates voltage, current, temperature profiles, and capacity data.

The originality of our methodology is characterized by four elements. The incorporation of spatial attention in a transductive LSTM framework enables the model to modify predictions according to the proximity of unseen test samples, a feature lacking in previous LSTM/GRU-based research. Secondly, the implementation of dilated convolutional layers facilitates efficient modeling of long-range dependencies without an overabundance of parameters. Third, we present a clustering-based DE initialization technique that improves the robustness of weight optimization and alleviates local minima challenges that constrain gradient-based training. Fourth, in contrast to traditional single-channel models, our many-to-one multi-channel design concurrently utilizes voltage, current, and temperature, enhancing generalization and diminishing parameter complexity. The contributions of this study are as follows:
An innovative amalgamation of spatial attention with TLSTM, facilitating context-aware predictions that harmonize global patterns with local adaptability.
Integration of dilated convolutional layers to effectively capture deterioration processes across extended temporal spans without incurring significant computing costs.
A clustering-based differential evolution technique for resilient weight initialization, improving optimization efficacy and prediction consistency.
A multi-channel many-to-one architecture that utilizes many sensor inputs, enhancing generalization and minimizing parameter overhead relative to traditional single-channel models.

The paper is organized as follows. Section “Literature review” provides a summary of recent research. Section “Methods” introduces the proposed model and describes its key components and approach. Section “Simulations and results” discusses the evaluation criteria and provides a thorough analysis of the results. Finally, Section “Conclusions” reports conclusions and future work.

sec.title: Literature review
sec.p: The precise forecasting of the remaining capacity (RCP) of lithium–ion batteries (LIBs) is essential for guaranteeing their safety, dependability, and performance, particularly in light of the escalating energy crises and environmental issues. The intricate aging mechanisms of LIBs substantially impede precise RCP, as conventional forecast techniques fail to adequately represent nonlinear degradation patterns and long-term relationships.

An novel paradigm that integrates evolutionary learning with deep learning for RCP is presented in20 to tackle these difficulties. The approach incorporates temporal convolutional networks (TCNs), bidirectional gated recurrent units (BiGRUs), and an attention mechanism to extract extensive features from time series and enhance prediction accuracy. A hybrid optimization approach is proposed that integrates the Sparrow Search approach (SSA) with Bayesian Optimization (BO) to improve model performance11 tackles the significant issue of forecasting the RUL of lithium–ion batteries, an essential factor in averting battery failure and enhancing their overall longevity. To attain this objective, novel techniques utilizing attention-based LSTM (Long Short-Term Memory), a specialized architecture particularly adept at forecasting values in time-series data, are proposed. The LSTM model has one-dimensional convolutional layers that enable the concurrent extraction of feature vectors, hence enhancing subsequent prediction processes through the integration of these vectors21 seeks to investigate battery RUL prediction from a fresh perspective, forecasting RUL based on data obtained from a restricted number of incomplete cycles, specifically 10 cycles, at each deterioration stage. A sophisticated deep learning framework, Attention-Aided Temporal Convolutional Memory Network (ATCMN), has been created to achieve precise and rapid battery RUL prediction under demanding conditions. A 3D tensor input structure is initially devised to incorporate the raw 10-cycle battery data, encompassing time, capacity, and temperature dimensions derived from the partial discharge process. To manage high-dimensional information, ATCMN initially constructs an attention module to automate the weighting of diverse battery metrics, temporal stages, and deterioration cycles within the input.

The precise estimation of the RUL of lithium–ion batteries is essential for the reliable functioning and prompt repair of the battery system. Measuring the capacity of an operational battery is challenging, and several predictive algorithms fail to convey uncertainty. To resolve this issue,22 introduces a hybrid prediction model that amalgamates particle swarm optimization (PSO), extreme learning machine (ELM), and relation vector machine (RVM). Initially, an indirect health index is derived and processed during the constant current charging phase. In the second stage, the correlation between the health index and capacity is determined using the RVM, and a predictive model for the health index is constructed based on the ELM. Particle Swarm Optimization (PSO) is employed to optimize the parameters of both the Relevance Vector Machine (RVM) and Extreme Learning Machine (ELM) models.

Reference23 presents an integrated deep learning methodology for forecasting the RUL of lithium–ion batteries by combining an autoencoder with a deep neural network (DNN). Initially, they introduce a multidimensional feature extraction technique utilizing an autoencoder model to depict battery health deterioration. The DNN utilizing the RUL prediction model is trained to assess the remaining cycle life of various batteries.

A transformer-based neural network is developed for RUL prediction in24. The battery capacity data is consistently rife with noise, particularly during charge/discharge regeneration cycles. To address this issue, they utilized a denoising autoencoder (DAE) to handle the unrefined data. Subsequently, to acquire temporal information and extract valuable features, a reconstructed sequence was input into a transformer network. Ultimately, they integrated the denoising and prediction activities into a unified system.

A method for predicting RUL of Lithium–Ion Batteries (LIBs) utilizing state decomposition and an enhanced transformer is proposed in25. Initially, to mitigate the effects of capacity degradation, the ensemble-wide empirical state decomposition with adaptive noise (CEEMDAN) method was employed to deconstruct the battery capacity decline into multi-scale sequences. Nonetheless, residual noise persists in the output of high-frequency data following CEEMDAN decomposition. To mitigate the influence of noise on prediction accuracy, high-frequency data is divided into multiple intricate subsequences by variable state decomposition. Ultimately, an enhanced transformer model retrieves both global and local characteristics from these subsequences to augment the precision of RUL prediction for lithium–ion batteries (LIBs).

An autoregressive model with exogenous variables (AREV) is introduced in26, which perpetually updates via a sliding window and forecasts battery health status and remaining useful life, thereby extending battery predictions from a fixed operating condition to various operating conditions. Moreover, in contrast to the majority of models that necessitate extensive datasets of identical battery types for training, the suggested model solely uses fragmented data from the target battery, approximately 30–50 cycles in length, to forecast capacity and ascertain battery lifespan based on failure criteria.

sec.title: Methods
sec.p: This study employs an innovative technique for initializing the weights of CNN, TLSTM, and spatial attention architectures. This approach employs an advanced DE strategy, incorporating a clustering mechanism and a newly developed fitness evaluation function. Our augmented DE technique utilizes a mutation and update procedure grounded in clustering, markedly enhancing the optimization effectiveness of weight initialization. This method seeks to improve initial weights, hence improving training efficiency and augmenting the performance of deep-learning models.

sec.title: Pre-training
Pre-processing
sec.p: The first phase in generating capacity degradation curves for four batteries entails a thorough data-cleaning process. Before incorporating the capacity degradation information into the experiment, any anomalous data points are replaced with the mean of closely related data. It is advisable to selectively use the data to enhance the learning efficiency of the TLSTM. Despite the abundance of voltage, current, and temperature readings during the charging cycles governed by the BMS configurations, using all data points is not optimal29. This decision involves choosing ten representative sample points from each charging cycle’s data, which includes voltage, current, and temperature measurements30.

sec.title: Clustering-based differential evolution
sec.p: DE32, a variation of evolutionary algorithms, is employed to address optimization problems. This collaborative improvement strategy seeks to determine the ideal resolution for a given function by persistently refining a set of possible solutions33. The operation of Differential Evolution entails generating new candidate solutions by synthesizing information from the current ensemble. This technique encompasses the processes of mutation, crossover, and selection. In mutation, a scaled disparity between two randomly chosen candidate solutions is added to another solution in the ensemble, resulting in a distinct outcome. Related efforts include cyber-physical diagnostics, material advances, and hybrid analytics. A digital twin framework with PINNs-e-RGCN improves fault detection under distributed sensors in complex systems34. Advances in the chemistry of P2-type sodium-ion cathodes are informing the aging mechanisms that shape observable signals35. For batteries, dual diagnostics (data- and model-based) integrate physics and learning for health assessment36, complementing multi-signal and prognostic-driven RUL modeling. DE is praised for its simplicity, efficiency, and versatility in tackling many improvement difficulties. Its application spans multiple domains, including engineering, finance, and artificial intelligence.

The mutation approach is crucial in determining the algorithm’s effectiveness, affecting the diversity of potential solutions within the population. An too aggressive mutation process might obliterate critical data within the population, resulting in premature convergence or stagnation. A mutation approach that is excessively permissive may inadequately explore the search space, resulting in sluggish advancement or inferior results. Numerous improvements have been proposed to reduce DE’s vulnerability to the mutation process. Some specialists have implemented adaptive mutation techniques that adjust the mutation intensity and scaling factor during optimization based on the overall performance of the group. Additional tactics include self-adjusting differential evolution, where the mutation intensity and scaling factor are intrinsic to the candidate solutions and evolve during the optimization process.

sec.title: Encoding strategy
sec.p:
In the presented DE algorithm, we utilize a vector formation technique for encoding the weights of the CNN, TLSTM, and spatial attention. Due to these networks’ intricate and nonlinear characteristics, accurately assigning weights to each neuron presents a formidable challenge. Hence, an encoding strategy is employed to systematically arrange the model’s weights into a vector format, facilitating effective utilization by the DE algorithm. Multiple trials were conducted to ascertain the most fitting encoding method, ultimately leading to the selection of the most optimal technique. The specific arrangement of the model’s weights is depicted in Fig. 3.Fig. 3
Illustration of encoding weights from CNN, TLSTM, and spatial attention into a vector for efficient utilization by the DE Algorithm.

sec.title: Objective function
TLSTM with spatial attention
sec.p: Long short-term memory (LSTM) networks are esteemed for their capacity to capture both short- and long-term relationships in sequential data, rendering them particularly adept for time-series prediction tasks like RUL estimate. In contrast to conventional statistical techniques, LSTMs adeptly manage variable-length input sequences and represent intricate temporal dynamics, which is crucial for characterizing nonlinear battery deterioration patterns.

Conventional LSTMs are generally trained as global models and may struggle to adjust predictions in proximity to unseen or novel samples. The transductive LSTM (TLSTM) modifies the conventional framework by calibrating its parameters based on the closeness of the evaluation point. Thus, TLSTM harmonizes global learning with local adaptation, enhancing accuracy in situations where degradation behavior displays inconsistencies, such as capacity regeneration.

To augment feature selection, we integrate a spatial attention mechanism into the TLSTM architecture. This module allocates differing significance to various input features such as voltage, current, temperature, and capacity enabling the network to concentrate on the most informative signals while mitigating the influence of extraneous or noisy variables. The attention weights are acquired during training and applied to the input matrix, yielding a weighted representation that highlights the elements most essential for predicting RUL.

sec.title: CNN-TLSTM network
sec.p: Traditional LSTM-based methods for RUL forecasting often depend on a one-to-one input–output framework, utilizing solely historical capacity sequences as input. This approach facilitates implementation but limits the integration of supplementary data, such as current, voltage, or temperature, which could yield critical insights into degradation dynamics. Consequently, these models may have difficulties in generalizing across diverse operational situations.

Feature extraction from these multidimensional inputs is performed via one-dimensional convolutional layers (1D CNNs). By traversing convolutional kernels along the temporal axis, CNNs proficiently identify local patterns and degradation signatures across various time scales. The retrieved temporal features are subsequently input into the TLSTM encoder, which utilizes transductive learning principles to adjust predictions for unobserved evaluation points.

Algorithm 1 delineates a systematic workflow of the proposed CNN–TLSTM framework, incorporating spatial attention and clustering-based differential evolution optimization. The procedure commences with data preparation to guarantee the consistency and dependability of the incoming signals. A clustering-based differential evolution technique is subsequently employed for weight initialization, improving convergence velocity and circumventing local minima. Subsequently, 1D CNN layers extract local temporal features, while the TLSTM, augmented with spatial attention, collects long-term dependencies and highlights the most informative input variables. Ultimately, RUL predictions are produced by iterative updates, wherein the integration of backpropagation and evolutionary optimization guarantees stability and robustness.

sec.title: Simulations and results
sec.p:
To assess the efficacy of the proposed CNN–TLSTM framework, extensive simulations were performed utilizing NASA’s lithium–ion battery dataset. To ensure reproducibility, all implementation specifics, hyperparameters, and training configurations are thoroughly documented. Weight initialization utilized a clustering-based DE technique, whereas training involved normalized datasets with a 70/15/15 partition for training, validation, and testing. The Adam optimizer, along with dropout regularization, was employed to improve convergence stability and prevent overfitting. sec.title: Training setup
sec.p: The NASA lithium–ion battery dataset was preprocessed prior to training to guarantee robust and consistent results. All raw measurements (voltage, current, temperature, and capacity) were standardized by min–max scaling to remove unit discrepancies and stabilize gradient descent. The dataset was further partitioned into training, validation, and testing sets utilizing a 70/15/15 ratio, hence assuring a fair representation of various degradation phases across the splits. Model training was conducted in Python utilizing the PyTorch framework, performed on an NVIDIA RTX GPU to enhance computational speed. The Adam optimizer was utilized with a constant learning rate, and early halting was implemented based on validation error to mitigate overfitting.

sec.title: Evaluation criteria
sec.p: The choice of evaluation criteria is crucial in the predictive modeling of battery health for objectively measuring model dependability and accuracy. Given that Remaining Useful Life forecasting encompasses sequential and nonlinear deterioration patterns, it is imperative to utilize error-based metrics that measure both the extent and ratio of prediction discrepancies. Metrics such as MAPE, RMSE, and MAE are extensively utilized in prognostics research due to their complementary insights: relative percentage errors enhance interpretability, squared errors underscore sensitivity to significant deviations, and absolute errors reflect overall prediction accuracy.

Root mean square error (RMSE)

Dataset
sec.p: This study’s tests utilized publicly accessible datasets from the NASA Prognostics Center of Excellence. These datasets have established a common baseline for assessing algorithms in prognostics and health management, especially with lithium–ion batteries. The selected records encompass extensive operating data from various rechargeable cells subjected to diverse load and usage situations until the batteries reached their end-of-life.

The repository offers comprehensive measurements for each cell, recorded during consecutive charge discharge cycles. The accessible signals comprise terminal voltage, load current, surface temperature, and capacity. These factors collectively represent both electrochemical behavior and thermal impacts, providing a more comprehensive understanding of battery degradation than capacity data alone. Specifically, voltage and current profiles while charging and discharging reveal dynamic responses, whilst temperature fluctuations offer further understanding of aging mechanisms affected by thermal conditions.

The collection prominently includes multiple operating profiles, encompassing different discharge rates and cut-off voltages. This unpredictability brings authentic complication, as batteries are seldom subjected to similar usage conditions in practice. Thus, the dataset serves as a suitable basis for evaluating the adaptability and generalization capacity of the suggested framework. All studies were performed in a controlled laboratory setting, reducing external factors such ambient temperature variations, thus guaranteeing the trustworthiness of the collected data.

The NASA PCoE lithium–ion battery aging dataset includes commercial 18,650 Li–ion cells (nominal capacity approximately 2 Ah) subjected to regulated charge, discharge, and electrochemical impedance spectroscopy (EIS) protocols at ambient temperature. Each cell is evaluated using synchronized channels for voltage, current, temperature, duration, and discharge capacity during several cycles until end-of-life. Charging was conducted in CC–CV mode; discharge utilized a continuous current of 2 A with model-specific cut-off voltages as detailed in Table 3. sec.title: Model performance
sec.p:
Our innovative algorithm was benchmarked against eight leading-edge models, encompassing MC-SVM30, SVM-DE11, LSTM-SLS33, TTP40, and HDBiLSTM21. It was compared with two variations: ‘Proposed (excluding TLSM),’ where TLSTM is substituted by a standard LSTM, and ‘Proposed (excluding dilated convolution),’ which excludes the dilated convolution in RUL predictions. The comparative analyses are showcased in Figs. 4, 5, 6, and 7, corresponding to Batteries #5, #6, #7, and #18. These figures offer an exhaustive examination of each model’s performance on a unified dataset. Remarkably, our algorithm demonstrated superior performance in all critical metrics. In particular, against the TTN model, our algorithm showed an impressive reduction in total error by 12%. Moreover, it excelled over MEDNNF, our nearest rival, in every evaluation aspect. The significant error diminution of our model underlines its enhanced efficacy. Regarding the primary metrics, RMSE and MAPE, our algorithm displayed error reductions exceeding 14% and 10%, respectively. These substantial improvements verify the predictive accuracy of our approach.Fig. 4

The comparison between ‘Proposed (excluding TLSM)’ and ‘Proposed (excluding dilated convolution)’ underscores the crucial contributions of TLSM and dilated convolution to our model. Including these elements led to estimated error rate reductions of around 10% and 9%, respectively.

To confirm the robustness of our model and its resistance to overfitting in both training and validation phases, Fig. 8 presents a detailed analysis of its effectiveness. This illustration visually traces the MAPE loss curves for both stages throughout the training period. Training loss is calculated each time the model completes a forward pass and adjusts weights during the backward pass of every epoch. In contrast, validation loss is computed after each epoch once the model runs a forward pass on the validation dataset without altering the weights. The training and validation losses should progressively decline, stabilizing at a low level. Such a trend indicates that the model efficiently assimilates information and generalizes aptly. However, if we observe a continuous decline in training loss but an increase in validation loss, it signals overfitting. This pattern suggests that the model is becoming excessively tailored to the training data’s noise, reducing its performance on unseen validation data.Fig. 8
Training and validation loss trajectories (0–300 epochs) on NASA PCoE Li–ion 18,650 cells: (a) Battery #5 (B0005), (b) #6 (B0006), (c) #7 (B0007), and (d) #18 (B0018).

sec.title: Analyze of the DE algorithm
sec.p:
Figure 9 graphically illustrates the target function’s evolution throughout successive DE process cycles. The horizontal axis represents the iteration or generation count, while the vertical axis indicates the target function’s corresponding values. This format offers a transparent view into the algorithm’s operational dynamics. A thorough examination of Fig. 9 reveals notable trends. Early stages show significant fluctuations in the target function’s values, highlighting the exploration phase of the DE algorithm. In this phase, the algorithm broadly searches the solution space, striving to circumvent early convergence on suboptimal solutions and identify promising areas. Progressing further, a clear shift towards stability is observed. The target function’s value fluctuations diminish, signaling a narrowing of the search. This stage focuses on refining the most viable solutions identified and deepening the search for the best result. It’s vital to watch for prolonged periods of no change in the target function values, as these might indicate that the algorithm has reached a local peak. Such situations may necessitate adjusting the algorithm’s settings or integrating additional techniques to enhance its exploration and navigation capabilities in the solution space.Fig. 9
Progression of the objective function through consecutive iterations using the DE algorithm.

sec.title: Runtime analysis
sec.p: A vital consideration for practical implementation is runtime efficiency. We analyzed the mean training duration per epoch among several models. Despite the incorporation of extra elements like dilated convolution and clustering-based optimization, CNN–TLSTM maintains a competitive and practical runtime for real-world applications.

Table 6 presents the runtime comparison of the proposed CNN–TLSTM model against baseline LSTM and GRU architectures, measured in seconds per training epoch. While the CNN–TLSTM requires slightly higher computational cost (2.1 s/epoch) due to the integration of dilated convolution and attention modules, the additional runtime remains modest compared to its performance gains. In contrast, the LSTM and GRU baselines are faster per epoch (1.8 and 1.6 s, respectively) but lack the predictive robustness demonstrated by the CNN–TLSTM.Table 6

sec.title: Discussion
sec.p: The findings indicate that integrating dilated 1-D convolutions with a spatial-attention TLSTM in a many-to-one framework consistently enhances RUL prediction for lithium–ion cells. The suggested model demonstrates minimal errors (MAPE 0.0053–0.0095) across NASA PCoE batteries B0005, B0006, B0007, and B0018, surpassing LSTM/GRU baselines and recent variants in RMSE, MAE, and MAPE metrics. The ablation investigations elucidate the sources of these improvements: The elimination of TLSTM or the dilated convolution bank diminishes accuracy, so affirming that multi-scale temporal filtering in conjunction with transductive sequence modeling is synergistic. The spatial-attention module enhances robustness by diminishing noisy or minimally informative segments while amplifying degradation-salient areas, which is especially advantageous during capacity-regeneration episodes and regime changes.

The training and validation trajectories demonstrate consistent convergence with a slight generalization gap, suggesting that the initialization and regularization technique is effective. The clustering-based Differential Evolution seeding expedites initial optimization and diminishes susceptibility to unfavorable initializations, as seen by the consistent convergence of the DE loss and the reduced variability of final errors. Statistical analyses conducted over multiple iterations validate that enhancements relative to baselines are statistically significant (P < 0.05), indicating that the observed improvements are not coincidental. Runtime analysis indicates a minor per-epoch overhead compared to standard LSTM/GRU (about 2.1 s against 1.6–1.8 s per epoch); nonetheless, the additional expense is negligible considering the accuracy improvements and is suitable for offline training and real BMS inference.

In addition to single-cell results, assessments on a supplementary dataset (e.g., CALCE) demonstrate that the model generalizes across operational profiles and measurement noise, underscoring the importance of incorporating voltage, current, and temperature with capacity. However, residual error spikes occur during sudden operational changes or at the end of life, where signals exhibit significant non-stationarity; these instances indicate that the integration of domain-shift detection or adaptive windows could enhance prediction stability. A further barrier is the range of chemistries: Although cylindrical 18,650 Li–ion cells are extensively studied, greater validation across various chemistries and formats would enhance external validity.

The study presents a practical and replicable pipeline utilizing dilated CNN features, spatial-attention TLSTM encoding, and clustering-based DE initialization that enhances accuracy while maintaining manageable complexity, in accordance with the limitations and data types of real-world battery management systems.

sec.title: Conclusions
sec.p: This study introduced an innovative and effective method for predicting the Remaining Useful Life of lithium–ion batteries. This technique combines TLSTM with one-dimensional dilated convolutional layers to address the critical problem of RUL prediction. This is essential for preventing battery failures and optimizing their operating longevity. The methodology utilizes several quantifiable parameters like as current, voltage, and temperature, resulting in exceptional accuracy in our model’s Remaining Useful Life predictions. The model’s many-to-one architecture improves flexibility to various input types while significantly reducing the required parameters, hence enhancing its generalization capability. Comprehensive evaluation of NASA’s lithium–ion battery datasets revealed the superiority of our TLSTM-based model over alternative deep-learning techniques.

Extending the model’s predictive capacity to assess the RUL over a prolonged duration is advantageous for strategic planning and optimizing the utilization of battery assets across various sectors. The capacity to precisely forecast RUL over an extended duration offers essential insights into the future functionality and condition of the battery, facilitating proactive maintenance plans and optimal resource distribution. In sectors where batteries are crucial for energy storage systems, including renewable energy integration, electric vehicles, and grid stability, strategic long-term planning is vital for maintaining consistent and dependable operations. By predicting RUL beyond the near term, operators and decision-makers can make educated decisions on battery replacement timelines, budget distributions, and resource management. In electric vehicle (EV) fleets, advanced knowledge of the RUL of individual batteries facilitates efficient replacement, hence minimizing vehicle downtime and lowering maintenance expenses. This method guarantees that battery replacements are systematically arranged during specified maintenance intervals, averting unforeseen failures that may result in operational interruptions. In renewable energy applications, where batteries are essential for storing surplus energy for future use, long-term Remaining Useful Life estimates enhance the optimization of energy storage capacity planning. By precisely predicting the RUL of battery banks, operators can plan battery replacement and expansion initiatives to correspond with anticipated long-term energy demands, thereby optimizing system efficiency and minimizing the frequency of replacements. Furthermore, in grid stabilization and industrial applications utilizing battery systems for peak shaving and load balancing, long-term remaining useful life projections enhance energy management and cost efficiency. Comprehending the projected RUL of batteries facilitates decisions about system enhancements, battery life-cycle management, and the identification of potential operational hazards linked to aging batteries. However, extending the prediction period presents specific challenges. In extending the prediction interval, the model must account for potential fluctuations in battery degradation patterns and operational conditions. Incorporating external factors such as diverse weather conditions, demand fluctuations, and temperature variations is essential for accurate long-term projections. To address these challenges, future research may explore advanced techniques such as transfer learning and reinforcement learning to enhance the model’s ability to adapt to changing situations across extended forecasting durations. Augmenting the model with more data inputs and improved feature development could more accurately depict long-term degradation trends.
